channel.title: Invaluable Experiences on Punit's Blogs
channel.description: Recent content in Invaluable Experiences on Punit's Blogs

item.title: Talks, Events and Workshops
item.description: I grew up in a household where my dad would tell to never hesitate on investing on my brain. He’d tell me to attend as many talks, conferences as possible even if it meant spending money to be part of these. I took the first part, for the second part not there yet, cause I always try to find student discounts or volunteering options to skip the “spending the money part” of his sentence. I have been to several talks and workshop now, but instead of listing each one of them here, rather I want to share in the order of how deep impact some of those had on me and something that I learnt from each of them

item.title: Community Support Officer
item.description:
My Role

My role is part of one of the most unique models across Australia. It provides pastoral care and support. Each day could look very different to the day before. Being in the university setting, I am in charge of providing pastoral care and support to the residents of the ANU’s residential Halls. I am also the first point of contact for over 500 people living in the building throughout the year afterhours from 4pm to midnight. Some of the things that I have dealt with but not restricited to are:

item.title: Senior Residential Mentor
item.description:
In the photo I am with my team of residential mentors at ANU’s residential Hall.

About

Responsibilities

Impact

Key Lessons Learned

Creating Boundaries

Setting expectations

Creating content

Here I refer to creating posters, having made countless of them now, I have good a good sense of marketing something to the public. In summary -

  1. Make the event details clear. As much as you might want to make it beautiful, it sometimes ends up becoming more complicated and misses the entire point of creating those posters/online posts in first place. If possible have clear bullet points
  • What?
  • When?
  • Where?

and around that you can show all the creativity you’d want.

item.title: AISA CyberCon 2024
item.description: Oh boy! was this a cool experience. One of the coolest in my life for sure!

item.title: Innovation ACT 2024 Winner
item.description:
My experience

It was fantastic to be part of the Innovationact program. I learned a lot about entrepreneurship and innovation, and I had the opportunity to work with some amazing people. The program was well-structured and provided a great balance of theory and practical experience. I would highly recommend it to anyone interested in starting their own business or working in the innovation space.

How It Started

The Process

We Won!

What I learned

  1. The importance of a strong team: A successful startup is built on the foundation of a strong team. I learned that having a diverse group of people with different skills and perspectives can lead to better decision-making and problem-solving.

item.title: Best Road trip with Strangers...
item.description:
With a group a wonderful people in this photo above, I hit the road to visit some of the schools in Rurual NSW for an entire week. Before I start I want to acknolowdge and credit to Jae and Imogen for setting up this brilliant program.
